message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of symmetrical rash over the knees and elbows, tense and grouped vesicles, and microabscesses in the papillary dermis suggests dermatitis herpetiformis, which is associated with gliadin-dependent hypersensitivity. Mite eggs and fecal pellets are associated with scabies, Nail pitting is seen in psoriasis, and Positive Nikolsky sign is seen in pemphigus vulgaris.

We refer to the details of the skin findings provided in the question stem. The presence of grouped vesicles, excoriation marks, and deposits of immunoglobulin A at the tips of dermal papillae are characteristic of dermatitis herpetiformis, which is associated with gliadin-dependent hypersensitivity. Option A describes scabies, which typically presents with burrows and may cause generalized itching but not necessarily grouped vesicles at specific locations. Nail pitting is seen in psoriasis and isn't related to the skin findings described in the question stem. Positive Nikolsky sign is seen in pemphigus vulgaris and other blistering diseases caused by autoantibodies to desmosomal proteins, where rubbing or pressure on the skin causes further separation of the layers of the epidermis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the skin rash with grouped vesicles and microabscesses in the papillary dermis, along with deposits of immunoglobulin A at the tips of dermal papillae, is most consistent with dermatitis herpetiformis, which is strongly associated with gluten sensitivity and gliadin-dependent hypersensitivity. Mite eggs and fecal pellets are associated with scabies, nail pitting with psoriasis, and a positive Nikolsky sign with pemphigus vulgaris.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presenting symptoms, including the symmetrical rash over the knees and elbows with vesicles, suggest dermatitis herpetiformis. There are often associated gastrointestinal changes related to gluten sensitivity, which makes Gliadin-dependent hypersensitivity the most likely option.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of immunoglobulin A deposits suggest that the skin findings are associated with an IgA-mediated disease. Among the options, only gliadin-dependent hypersensitivity is IgA-mediated, and it is associated with dermatitis herpetiformis, which presents with a symmetrical rash over the knees and elbows with tense, grouped vesicles, and several excoriation marks.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of immunoglobulin A at the tips of dermal papillae and a symmetrical rash over the knees and elbows suggest dermatitis herpetiformis, which is associated with Gliadin-dependent hypersensitivity. Mite eggs and fecal pellets are associated with scabies, nail pitting with psoriasis, and a positive Nikolsky sign with pemphigus vulgaris.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest dermatitis herpetiformis, which is associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathy (celiac disease). This relates to option (B). Option (A) is associated with scabies, option (C) is associated with psoriasis, and option (D) is associated with pemphigus vulgaris.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symmetrical rash with grouped vesicles, microabscesses in the papillary dermis, and deposits of immunoglobulin A at the tips of dermal papillae are characteristic of dermatitis herpetiformis, which is associated with Gliadin-dependent hypersensitivity. Mite eggs and fecal pellets are associated with scabies, nail pitting is associated with psoriasis, and positive Nikolsky sign is associated with pemphigus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest dermatitis herpetiformis, which is associated with gluten sensitivity and gliadin-dependent hypersensitivity. The other options are not associated with the specific symptoms and findings described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of grouped vesicles and immunofluorescence deposits of immunoglobulin A at the tips of dermal papillae suggest dermatitis herpetiformis, which is associated with gliadin-dependent hypersensitivity. Option A is associated with scabies, option C is associated with psoriasis, and option D is associated with pemphigus vulgaris.
